page.title: 01Inchlaggan, Glen Garry
page.content: Inchlaggan, a community of nine households, six of which are timber construction, is situated in an oak and birch wood overlooking Loch Garry. Recently planted coniferous forests have made life difficult for the indigenous red deer as well as adding to the acidity of the heavy rains. This in turn, appears to be the case of the reduction of salmon and trout fishing. This peaceful hamlet does not have the benefit of mains water or sewage disposal. Garbh Allt (Gaelic for 'Rough Burn' -stream) provides soft, peaty, untreated water by a small dam. After use, waste is disposed of via a biological sewerage treatment tank which deposits clean water back into the burn The water is unused - simply borrowed. One two households have a fully employed member, two are holiday homes, three
